main_text:
In philosophy, “self-knowledge” standardly refers to
knowledge of one’s own mental states—that is, of what one
is feeling or thinking, or what one believes or desires. At least
since Descartes, most philosophers have believed that self-knowledge
differs markedly from our knowledge of the external world (where this
includes our knowledge of others’ mental states). But there is
little agreement about what precisely distinguishes self-knowledge
from knowledge in other realms. Partly because of this disagreement,
philosophers have endorsed competing accounts of how we achieve
self-knowledge and of its epistemic status. These accounts have
important consequences for a broad range of issues in epistemology,
the philosophy of mind, and moral psychology.

This entry focuses on knowledge of one’s own mental states. A
separate topic sometimes referred to as “self-knowledge”
is knowledge about a persisting self. This topic is addressed in a
supplement:
 Knowledge of the Self.
